q.q: do you ever think of chords/voicings as a stack of intervals instead?

q.a: visualize it on the piano keyboard
q.q:
Like, M3m3 would be a major chord expressed by a major third followed by a minor third. But in first inversion itd be m3P4, a minor third with a perfect fourth after it. Kind of what the idea is with roman numeral inversions, having I be root, I6 be first inversion (with implied third as middle voice, and the 6th being the top voice interval with bass note), and I64 for second inversion, (6th and 4th intervals from bass). Except this system ive been trying to figure out would show the relationship between each note to their closest note up and down. Ideally itd show all relationships, But I think intervals as a unit make sense trying to categorize chords not only by what notes are being played, but their inversions. Sometimes it feels like this way "harmony" or "notation" would make more sense. Best way I can think of it is a stack of geometry upwards like a totem, or stacked figures using the same center (with their corners touching the same imaginary circle).

Do you have a specific way you visualize/categorize relationships in music

q.a: 'perfect pitch' means absolute pitch but i think it's a misleading name. i think 'perfect pitch' is a misleading name for absolute pitch because it sounds like it means 'having a perfect sense of pitch' like knowing if something is in tune or not. but that's not quite what absolute pitch means. absolute pitch is a very non musical ability, and there is shockingly little crossover between great musicianship and great absolute pitch. absolute pitch means you can tell if the note you're hearing now is in tune with some other note you heard in your childhood. but what really counts in music is whether you can tell if a note you're hearing now is in tune with other notes that are also happening now

q.a: it depends what you mean by record, but i can overcome almost any restriction. for example if i have no instrument but i have my phone, i can explain how it goes, sing it and explain any necessary contextual info to understanding what it's made of. if i absolutely cannot speak or make any sound, i could use staff paper but 99% of the time if i can't speak then i am likely in a situation with no staff paper. but i have a number system i can use to write melodies on paper without staffs, but let's face it, paper and pencil wouldn't usually be available unless i could speak. so really in that case we're talking about phone text. i do have a system of fully writing down melody, lyric, and chord information using only phone text. unfortunately it takes 3 full lines of information just to convey 1 line, plus any additional descriptive info needed, plus autocorrect kicks your ass on that stuff, but it can be done. it's rare that i would need that, and typically that gets used the most on airplanes. in the rare situation where i have absolutely no writing device available (no phone, etc), then i would need to engage in deep mental communication activities to try to remember the situation from as many angles as possible (in other words, pretend i wrote it down and imagine every logistical aspect of what that would contain, and imagine explaining it to someone else who knew nothing about it) and keep analyzing it in different ways until the documentation tools become available, which usually would not be that far in the future. but most of the time there is at least voice memo or phone text available

q.a:
3/7 i did some experiments with editing improv sessions and putting captions on them. 3/8 i visited a friend in new jersey. 3/9 i visited a friend in long beach ny, and also did a songwriting session. 3/10 more editing of improv sessions. also did a new improv session. 3/10 i started studying everything that came up in google autofills for every letter, just to learn more about the world i live in. also did some improv/journal edits. then for the next several days i did some extensive research trying to figure out where food comes from (it seemed important at the time). then i had some songwriting breakthroughs. then mostly spent the rest of the year trying to write and record songs. after a few more years of writing, recording, organizing, and general confusion, when i finally had a website and a very rigid 5-day a week content schedule, the format you mentioned found a happy home on thursdays, and was switched to tuesdays several weeks later. so i did not stop at 3, there are at least 20 videos made in this format, most of them being made in 2014, released on thursdays, then tuesdays, then on various different days during the later part of 2014. i just found the list, it's more than 20

q.q: In a Philosophize This Podcast, there is discussion between Faciticty and Trancendance. Facticity is the third person perspective that any other person can take. These facts include biological facts about height, weight, race, gender, skin color, eye color, etc. However, these facts also include social and economic, psychological and historical facts as well. Transcendence is the first person perspective of a human being. With transcendence, human beings can "transcend" their facticity and become something more than they are or seem to be. This "something" they can become is a result of that human beings individual choices or decisions, and many turn it in to a tug-a-war situation in life. People who want both 100% of transcendence and facticity basically want to be god is some sort, "can do no wrong but has ultimate power". So my question is what is your take on this, is there a possible balance you choose when it comes between the two?

q.a: just find the harmonies 1 note at a time. go thorugh the entire song and add just 1 note to 1 moment. see if you can find that special moment that really needs it, and find out which note it needs. I'll give you one to get started. "Celebrate good times come on", that party song from the 70s. playing that vocal part all the way through, no band, no harmony, and i have to decide 1 moment to add 1 note. i'm gonna say for "come on", not the first but every 2nd and 4th time of "come on" in the choruses, let's add a maj 3rd above the voc melody. so if the song is in Ab, let's add the C note above "come on", not the first time but the second and 4th time it occurs in the choruses. ok now you pick a song, with just the melody, and pick what you think is the most important spot to add 1 note to. or if you want, you can find another one for the song i did

q.a: first thing, think about the entire song not just the chords. if there's melody and lyrics in the song, do everything in service of that. and the other thing you might want to practice is playing all chords within a very small range. the order of notes you may have learned in school is kind of a myth. chords don't really belong in that order. i think if you play through some charts and deliberately play everything right around the middle C range, flipping as necessary to fit in that range, i think you will learn very quickly. also put the bass note an octave or 2 below, and if the chord has more then 4 notes then leave the bass note out of the right hand. i think you will learn things very quickly that way

q.a: if it's an ambiguous case, i generally will gravitate toward the 'ionian perspective' as you call it. i would surely consider Latch in Ab, especially when you look at the melody. Some songs may be much more strongly anchored to that 2 root, where you would definitely wanna say 2 dorian. like miles davis "so what", no one is going to say that's in C. or "uptown funk", no one's gonna say that's in C. it clearly lives its life in D dorian, period. There are many many ambiguous cases, especially when you can't decide whehter to take the "ionian perspective" or the relative minor ("aeolian perspective", as you might say). Like a song that is firmly in A minor in the verse, then does F C G G for the chorus, obviously the chorus is in C. Or the ever so popular perpetually looping Amin F C G sequence, that's the most famously ambiguous case. The whole thing sounds like it's in C except that the first chord is actually Amin. Some songs are ambiguous as to which way you'd call it, but the melody is really what holds the answers
q.q: Hi Bill. I saw a video about Disclosure's song "Latch" where it said the song was in Bb dorian and went i > v > IV > III. Someone in the comments said no, it's clearly in Ab major and goes ii > vi > V > IV. Someone else said no, it's in F minor and goes iv > i > VII > VI. It was all a bit silly and it made me wonder if I should just analyze all songs in a major key even if they're minor or another mode. E.g. it seems a lot easier to just remember that vi > IV sounds cool rather than remembering both vi > IV and i > VI since they are the same notes. Do you see any downsides in only thinking about chords from an "ionian perspective"? (this might be a cool math rock band name) Or are there benefits in calling the vi chord the i chord if the song is in a minor key?

q.a: sure

q.a: astrology is often hijacked and re-purposed as a 12-option personality test, but that's not what real astrology actually is
q.q:
I personally hate astrology, but I have a couple of friends/acquaintances/family members who are into it and from what I can tell, the attraction of astrology isn't that it can predict the future. 99% of astrology fans don't know if Mercury is in retrograde or what that even means. They couldn't identify a single one of the zodiac constellations in the actual night sky.

The attraction of astrology is that it's an elaborate personality test that encourages a lot of self-reflective navel-gazing, which some people enjoy and find beneficial. For instance, the "typical" positive Aries traits are courage, daring and competitiveness, while the negative traits are self-centeredness, anger and pushiness. Obviously, not every person born in the month of April has these as their dominant traits... but pretty much everyone has these traits present to some extent, so they'll reflect on this crude psychological assessment. An Aries who actually is dari ng and c ompetitive might acknowledge that they come off as rude or attention-seeking to others. And an Aries who's naturally shy might feel empowered by a personality test that tells them that deep down, they're courageous and decisive. Astrology books that promise to give relationship tips for Capricorns and Libras (or whatever) are actually just full of basic good communication advice that will probably smooth a relationship between any two people. So people can feel like they're getting real benefit from astrology.

If people really don't feel like their personality fits their sign, they can get a fancy natal chart done that will tell them that even though their sign in Taurus, the position of Jupiter or whatever counteracts their Taurus traits and makes them a true Scorpio. Astrology is just a very elaborate, mystical personality test that you can manipulate to get whatever results you want. It's really not that different from the MBTI personality test, which is extrem ely popu lar among "rational" people even though it's junk science. People like personality tests and astrology because people like thinking about themselves and coming up with fancy terms to express their identity.
